sourcesContent: import React from 'react'; import { Box, Typography, Grid, Paper, Chip, Divider } from '@mui/material'; import { BarChart, Bar, XAxis, YAxis, CartesianGrid, Tooltip, Legend, ResponsiveContainer, LineChart, Line, ComposedChart, ScatterChart, Scatter } from 'recharts'; import { salesData, productData } from '../data/analyticsData'; const FindingCard = ({ title, observation, evidence, severity }) => ( {title} {observation} Evidence: {evidence} ); const Diagnostic = () => { // Compute correlations for display const priceSalesCorrelation = salesData.map(d => ({ ...d, priceImpact: d.price > 120 ? 'High Price Zone' : 'Normal' })); const returnVsMargin = productData.map(d => ({ ...d, risk: d.returnRate > 10 ? 'High Risk' : 'Low Risk' })); return ( {/* Header */} üîç Diagnostic Analytics "Why did it happen?" ‚Äî Root cause analysis through data correlation {/* Key Question */} üîé Key Questions Being Investigated Why did sales drop by 33% in March? Is there a correlation between price changes and sales volume? Are customer complaints linked to competitor activity? Which product categories have the highest return risk? {/* Chart 1: Price vs Sales Correlation (FULL WIDTH) */} Finding 1: Price ‚Üî Sales Inverse Correlation When unit price increases beyond ‚Çπ120, sales volume consistently drops. The orange line (price) and blue bars (sales) move in opposite directions. ‚ö†Ô∏è Conclusion: March price increase (‚Çπ100 ‚Üí ‚Çπ150, +50%) directly caused a 50% sales drop. {/* Chart 2: Complaints vs Competitor */} Finding 2: Complaints Spike Pattern Complaint surges align with months where competitors launched discount offers. üî¥ Marked months (Mar, Oct, Nov) had active competitor discount campaigns. Finding 3: Product Return Risk Clothing has the highest return rate (15%), eroding its 45% margin. {/* Findings Summary */} üìã Diagnostic Summary ); }; export default Diagnostic;
